context:
Chicken Pie

3 to 4 lb. hen or 6 chicken breasts
1 to 2 sticks margarine
salt and pepper to taste
biscuit dough (approximately 2 c.)
2 Tbsp. flour, dissolved in cold water with 1 c. milk added (add this to broth)

1. Cook chicken until tender; remove all bones and skin.
2. In large pan, arrange layer or chicken and 1/2 cup margarine.
3. Roll dough and cut in strips.
4. Place over chicken.
5. Alternate this step until all chicken has been used, then pour chicken broth over this and roll top crust.
6. Place on pie and slit in center.
7. Brush top with butter.
8. Bake in a 350° to 375° oven until golden brown.

Turnip Greens

1 c. bacon grease
1 Tbsp. salt
1/4 tsp. baking soda

1. Wash greens in cold water to remove grit or any dirt.
2. In a large pot filled 3/4 full of water, add the bacon grease and salt. Bring to a boil.
3. Add the greens by the handful to the pot, letting them have a
4. little time to start to cook down before adding more.
5. When pot is full, you will need to poke the greens down for a few minutes as they like to come to the top of the pot and run over.
6. Add 1/4 teaspoon of baking soda to the greens to take the bitterness out.
7. Cook at a boil until greens are tender, perhaps a half hour.
8. Drain well.
9. While greens are draining in the colander, cut them up using two knives.

Funnel Cake

1 egg, beaten
2/3 c. milk
1 1/4 c. flour
2 Tbsp. sugar
1 tsp. baking powder
1/4 tsp. salt
oil (for deep frying)
powdered sugar

1. Beat egg and milk.
2. Blend dry ingredients and add to egg and milk, beating constantly, until smooth.
3. Hold finger over a 3/8 or 1/2-inch funnel hole and fill funnel with batter.
4. Have oil heated to 375°.
5. Release finger and drop batter in a circular motion, starting in center to form a spiral.
6. Repeat with more dough, forming more cakes, until pan is crowded.
7. Fry until puffy and golden brown.
8. Remove from oil with slotted spoon and drain on paper towel.
9. Cool slightly and dust with powdered sugar.
10. Makes about 24.

Ultimate Chocolate Cake

3 oz. unsweetened chocolate
1 c. unsalted butter
2 1/3 c. firmly packed light brown sugar
2 1/3 c. sifted cake flour
2/3 c. buttermilk
1 c. boiling water
1 tsp. vanilla
3 large eggs
2 tsp. baking soda
1 tsp. salt

1. Heat oven to 350°.
2. Brush cake pans with melted butter and dust with sifted flour, shaking out excess.
3. Chill until needed.
4. Melt chocolate in the top of a double boiler.
5. Allow to cool.
6. Cream together butter and sugar.
7. Add eggs, one at a time, beating well. Mix in melted, cooled chocolate.
8. Sift together flour, baking soda and salt and add gradually to chocolate mixture, alternating with buttermilk.
9. Stir in boiling water and vanilla.
10. Pour batter into prepared cake pans.
11. Bake for 30 minutes or until a cake tester comes out clean.
12. Cool for several minutes in pans.
13. Invert onto wire rack and cool before filling and decorating.

7. Stir in remaining ingredients; cook until cheese melts, stirring constantly. Gradually stir cheese mixture into vegetable mixture.

Microwave Caramel Corn

1 1/2 c. peanuts (optional)

1/4 c. light corn syrup

1. Pop corn in air popper.
2. Place popcorn and peanuts in double brown grocery bag; set aside.
3. Combine sugar, butter, syrup and salt in glass bowl.
4. Microwave on High 3 to 4 minutes, stirring after each minute, until mixture boils.

7. Close bag; shake well.

1. Remove garlic skins; peel away tomato skins and blend 1 clove garlic and 3 tomatoes in your electric blender.
2. Now add 1 onion (cut in quarters), 1 green pepper (cut in quarters) and 1 cucumber (peeled and cut in cubes) to blender mixture and blend again. Strain mixture into a large serving bowl.
3. Blend together eggs, vinegar, salt, cayenne and tomato juice long enough to mix thoroughly.
4. Stir into the serving bowl and chill in refrigerator. Add oil before serving.

Cocido Castellano(Castillian Bean Soup; One Pot Meal)

1 piece smoked bacon (2 x 2 x 3-inch cube)

collards and another onion
lettuce, tomatoes, lemon salt,
olive oil

1. Soak beans overnight (8 to 10 hours) in saltwater 3-inches over beans.
2. When ready to cook, drain off saltwater.
3. Put garbanzo beans, ham hock, sausage, soup bone, bacon and onion in boiling water and cook about 4 hours.
4. When it has cooked about 3 1/2 hours, taste.
5. Add salt if needed.
6. Saute onions in oil.
7. Add collards and pepper to taste; stir-fry.
8. Add water if needed.
9. Cook until done.
10. Next prepare fresh salad of lettuce, tomato, etc. After bean soup is cooked, strain liquid into another pot.
11. This broth is then brought to a boil (be sure to taste for salt, pepper, etc.) and use to cook the vermicelli.
12. While soup is cooking (15 to 20 minutes) separate bones and gristle or fat (skins).
13. On a large platter or shallow serving dish, arrange garbanzos, meat and collards.
14. Put salad in separate bowl.
15. The vermicelli soup should be served and eaten first.
16. Then, the main course.

Chippewa Soup

1. Soak the split peas overnight.
2. In a large pot (preferably 3-4 gallons) heat a small amount of oil until very hot.
3. Add the carrots, onions and celery and sweat the vegetables.
4. Add the garlic and sweat a few more minutes.
5. Add the curry powder to the vegetables and stir until curry is thoroughly mixed with the vegetables.
6. Add all remaining ingredients to the pot.
7. Bring this to a boil, reduce heat and simmer for approximately three hours. Adjust the seasoning with salt and pepper.
8. Remove the bay leaves and puree the soup through a food mill or in an electric blender. Chill thoroughly.
9. This is the base for Chippewa Soup.

One-Rise Monkey Bread

2 Tbsp. sugar
1 tsp. salt
1 pkg. active dry yeast
1 c. very warm water (120~ to 130~)
2 Tbsp. butter or margarine, softened
1 egg
1/3 c. butter or margarine
poppy seed (optional)

1. Grease a 12-cup fluted tube pan or a 10-inch tube pan.
2. In large bowl blend 1 1/2 cups flour, sugar, salt, yeast, water, margarine and egg at low speed until moistened.
3. Beat three minutes at medium speed.
4. Stir in remaining flour by hand.
5. Knead dough on floured surface until smooth, about 1 minute.
6. Press or roll dough to 15 x 12-inch rectangle.
7. Using sharp knife, cut dough into diamond-shaped pieces by cutting into 2 inch strips diagonally across dough.
8. In shallow pan melt 1/3 cup butter.
9. Dip each piece of dough in melted butter and place in prepared pan, making layers. Sprinkle each layer with poppy seeds.
10. Cover; let rise in warm place until light and doubled in size, 45 to 60 minutes.
11. Heat oven to 375°.
12. Bake 20 to 25 minutes.
13. Cool in pan 2 minutes.
14. Invert into serving pan.
15. Makes a 10-inch pull apart loaf.

Funnel Cake

1 egg, beaten
2/3 c. milk
1 1/4 c. flour
2 Tbsp. sugar
1 tsp. baking powder
1/4 tsp. salt
oil (for deep frying)
powdered sugar

1. Beat egg and milk.
2. Blend dry ingredients and add to egg and milk, beating constantly, until smooth.
3. Hold finger over a 3/8 or 1/2-inch funnel hole and fill funnel with batter.
4. Have oil heated to 375°.
5. Release finger and drop batter in a circular motion, starting in center to form a spiral.
6. Repeat with more dough, forming more cakes, until pan is crowded.
7. Fry until puffy and golden brown.
8. Remove from oil with slotted spoon and drain on paper towel.
9. Cool slightly and dust with powdered sugar.
10. Makes about 24.

Apple Cobbler

1/2 c. (1 stick) margarine
2 c. sugar
2 c. water
1 1/2 c. flour (self-rising)
1/2 c. shortening
1/3 c. milk
2 c. chopped apples
1 tsp. cinnamon
1/2 c. chopped walnuts

1. Heat oven to 350° and melt margarine in a 13 x 9 x 2-inch pan. In a saucepan, heat sugar and water until sugar melts.
2. Cut shortening into flour until particles are fine crumbs.
3. Add milk and stir.
4. Turn onto floured board and knead until smooth.
5. Roll dough into large rectangle; spread apples and sprinkle with cinnamon.
6. Roll up and slice into 1 1/2-inches and lay apple, side up carefully in pan.

Brownie Pie

1 c. sugar
2 eggs

1 tsp. vanilla
1/2 c. chopped nuts

1. Place flour, cocoa and sugar in a large mixing bowl.
2. Stir to mix well.
3. Add eggs, margarine, salt and vanilla.
4. Beat with a whisk for about 4 minutes.
5. Stir in nuts.
6. Pour into a greased 8-inch pie pan and bake in preheated 325° oven until done, about 30 to 40 minutes.
7. Pie will puff up and then settle down.

Ribbon Layer Jello

4 (3 oz.) pkg. jello, make each pkg. separately
1 c. hot water for each pkg. jello
1/2 c. cold water for each pkg. jello
2 pkg. Knox gelatine
2 c. milk
2 tsp. vanilla
1 c. sugar
1 pt. sour cream

1. Dissolve Knox gelatine in 1/2 cup cold water; put aside. Bring to a boil, milk and sugar.
2. Add gelatine mixture, sour cream and vanilla.
3. Beat until thick, about 10 minutes, with electric mixer.
4. Separate this into 3 parts.
5. Layer jello in desired order.
6. (Red on top for Christmas or green on top for St. Pat's day.
7. Christmas layers are green, white mixture, orange white mixture, yellow white mixture and red.)
8. Let each layer set 45 minutes before adding next layer.
9. Mix each jello separate before making layers.
10. Time consuming but very decorative.

answers.text: 4 (3 oz.) pkg. jello, make each pkg. separately
